title: Unilateral Progressive High-Frequency Sensorineural Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I had a hearing test years ago that showed mild hearing loss in my left ear, but I feel like my hearing in that ear has declined in the last few months.

problem_summary.onset: Original mild loss noted years ago; recent decline noticed over the last few months.
problem_summary.course: Progressive in the left ear; stable/normal in the right.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Denies tinnitus, dizziness, otalgia, or aural pressure/fullness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Subjective decline in hearing ability in the left ear.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a history of mild high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear diagnosed years ago. She reports a subjective decline in left ear hearing over the past few months. Right ear hearing is reported as normal.
history.otologic_history: Denies otalgia, aural pressure, or fullness. Denies tinnitus or dizziness.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal hearing sensitivity (0-10 dB HL). Left ear shows normal sensitivity 250-1000 Hz, sloping to mild loss at 2000 Hz, then steeply sloping to moderately-severe/severe loss at 3000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT agrees with PTA for both ears. Word recognition is excellent (100%) in the right ear but reduced (76%) in the left ear.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral reflexes are normal. Left ipsilateral reflexes are elevated/absent. Contralateral reflexes are elevated or absent bilaterally. Reflex decay could not be tested due to elevated thresholds.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a steeply sloping, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Word recognition is reduced in the left ear (76%) compared to the right (100%). Acoustic reflexes demonstrate a retrocochlear pattern, with elevated or absent thresholds particularly in the left ear and contralateral conditions, despite normal tympanometry.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms the decline you noticed in your left ear, specifically in the high pitches.
While the right ear is hearing normally, the pattern of hearing loss in the left ear, combined with the reflex test results, warrants further investigation.
We are referring you to an ENT specialist for a medical evaluation, which will likely include an MRI to rule out any structural causes on the hearing nerve.
We will discuss hearing aid options or other interventions after the medical evaluation is complete.
notes_for_actor: You are calm but concerned about the recent change in your left ear.
You do not have dizziness or ringing (tinnitus), just the hearing drop.
Emphasize that you had a 'mild' loss years ago, but this feels different/worse recently.
